instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with liquid coffee damage primary around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area. Replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>. Board now takes a constant 430ma and CPU gets warm but PCH side burning warm with no fan spin. Checked all SPI resistors and all measure good. Continuity is good as well. Tried known good Bios with no change.

What to check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Clean J6100; remove it, if do not use medusa programmer.

Check all voltages from pages 57/58.
Also check voltage on the L/C blocks located between CPU and board edge.

Reball SMC.
Heat PCH/CPU with quality flux; try to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8S3_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> only 0.181V

Where does <SIGNAL>PP1V8S3_EN</SIGNAL> signal come from?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
The board consumes 340mA without <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?
You can only have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS and RTC voltage.
If CPU gets hot, one of these rails should have very low resistance to ground.

Post <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; discard any short on them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
As expected, low value on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and even short on <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
This looks like dead CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Bummer. Are CPUs still impossible to find for these? We do have a BGA machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
CPU is not cheap and very easy you can get a refurbished/dead chip.
Change it is also dificil job...
